newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity futures rise in moderate volume.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity futures rise in moderate volume.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures were trading higher in moderate volume under some pressure from anticipated spring and summer cooling demand, industry sources said.

Trade of the May power contracts as front months signalled a move away from the shoulder, or low-demand months, towards the head, or heavy-demand months when prices should trade higher, the sources said.
"We were in the shoulder, now we're getting closer to the head," said one New York-based futures trader.

As of 1225 EST, May California Oregon Border (COB) was trading up 30 cents at $10.55 after exchanges as low as $10.30, while June COB was up 19 cents at $10.90 after reaching as low as $10.85 per megawatt hour (MWh).
May Palo Verde (PV) was trading up 35 cents at $14.90 after reaching as low as $14.60, while June was up 60 cents at $16.20 from a low of $15.80 per MWh.
NYMEX said as of 1200 EST an estimated total of 33 COB and 83 PV contracts had traded.
As of 1235 EST, NYMEX May Henry Hub natural gas futures were trading down 0.4 cents at $1.88 per million British thermal units.

In Western news, capacity on the Pacific Intertie power transmission system, which links the Northwest to Southern California, will be raised to 6,250 megawatts (MW) by this weekend, a spokesman for Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) said Wednesday.
BPA says it will be able to raise the Intertie capacity even without re-energizing the 500 KV John Day-Slatt line, although repairs to the line are also expected to be finished by Saturday.

Several generation plant outages continued in the U.S., including talk of an outage at the 750 MW unit 2 at the Navajo coal-fired power plant, although the status of the unit could not immediately be confirmed.
Southern California Edison said restart of the 1,070 MW unit 2 at the San Onofre nuclear power plant has been delayed by another week to April 1.
Also, the 1,158 MW WNP-2 nuclear plant in Washington will be shut Thursday, several weeks earlier than planned for maintenance due to ample hydropower in the region.
In the Northwest, temperatures would average near normal along the coast and about 10 degrees Fahrenheit above normal in the extreme eastern area for the next several days.
In the Southwest, readings would run as much as nine degrees above normal in the northeast, but two to six degrees above normal through the rest of the region.
COB open interest for March 25 fell 66 to 3,628, while PV open interest fell 62 to 3,264, NYMEX said.
